question: What is the probable genetic defect in this child with recurrent infections, tetany, oral candidiasis & a heart murmur?
exp: Digeorge syndrome: Caused by 22q deletion C- Cardiac anomaly A- Abnormal facies (hypeelorism, antimongoloid slant, sho philtrum, mandibular hypoplasia. T- Thymic hypoplasia C- Cleft palate H- Hypocalcemia

question: A child with pigment dilution of skin and eyes, hemorrhagic diathesis, ceroid deposition within the reticuloendothelial system has:-
exp: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome Oculocutaneous albinism Ceroid accumulation in lysosomes Prolonged bleeding time. Bloom syndrome: Erythema and telangiectasia on face after exposure to sunlight Immunodeficiency, GI malabsorption and hypogonadism are common. Alezzandrini syndrome: Deafness Vitiligo Poliosis Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome: Vitiligo associated with uveitis Dysacusia Meningoencephalitis

question: The commonest primary immunodeficiency is?
exp: Isolated IgA Deficiency: commonest immunodeficiency (1/600) Affected individuals have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA C/F: asymptomatic, recurrent respiratory infections

question: In genetic deficiency of MPO, the increased susceptibility to infection is due to:
exp: In MPO deficiency there is decreased microbial killing because of defective MPO--H2. O2 system, so there is an inability to produce hydroxyl halide radicals.
opc: Inability to produce hydroxyl halide radicals

question: 22q11 deletion leading to Di George syndrome is associated with:-
exp: DIGEORGE SYNDROME/ VELO CARDIO FACIAL SYNDROME: C- Cardiac defects A- Abnormal facies T- Thymic hypoplasia C- Cleft palate H- Hypocalcemia (d/t hypothyroidism) 22- 22q deletion

question: "Hereditary angioneurotic edema" is due to deficiency of:
exp: Hereditary angioneurotic edema occurs due to deficient or defective C1 inhibitor Protein S deficiency- | risk of venous thrombosis

question: Class IV lupus nephritis is:
exp: Classification of Lupus Nephritis Class I Minimal Mesangial Lupus Nephritis Class II Mesangial Proliferative Lupus Nephritis Class III Focal Proliferative Lupus Nephritis Class IV Diffuse Proliferative Lupus Nephritis Class V Membranous Lupus Nephritis Class VI Advanced Sclerotic Lupus Nephritis

question: Which of the following can be seen in SCID?
exp: SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency) Combined deficiency of B & T cells seen; so autoimmune ds, granuloma formation & graft rejection are absent GVHD which is due to immune-competent cells attacking an immunosuppressed host can still be seen

question: Which of the following is not found in Di. George's syndrome?
exp: Disease Primary defect Secondary defect Di. George Syndrome (Thymic Hypoplasia) 22q11 deletion Failure of development of 3rd & 4th pharyngeal pouches T-cell defect Tetany Congenital defects of heart and great vessels Mucocutaneous candidiasis

question: Most sensitive antibody for SLE:
exp: Autoantibodies in Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) Antibody Clinical Utility Antinuclear antibodies Best screening test/Most sensitive Anti-ds DNA Specific, correlate with disease activity, nephritis, vasculitis Anti-Sm Most Specific for SLE, marker for CNS lupus Anti-RNP Not specific for SLE Anti-Ro/La (SS-A) Sicca syndrome, neonatal lupus with congenital heart block Anti-histone Drug-induced lupus

question: Tonsils are absent in:
exp: Tonsils are absent in X linked agammaglobulinemia
